description: FirstEnergy's Pennsylvania utilities (Met-Ed, Penn Power, and West Penn Power) offer a Commercial & Industrial Demand Response Program as part of Pennsylvania Act 129 energy efficiency and conservation requirements. The program is administered by approved Demand Response Program Service Providers (CPower and EnerNOC Inc.) selected by FirstEnergy. Commercial, industrial, governmental, and institutional customers can earn financial incentives by reducing electricity demand during peak hours when requested by the utility. Load reduction techniques include temporarily reducing or shutting down industrial processes, turning off lights in groups or sequences, reducing HVAC system usage, shutting down large motors and compressors, or starting back-up generation. By participating, customers agree to allow FirstEnergy to retain ownership of all PJM Capacity Rights associated with demand reduction measures (unless customers have existing contracts with third-party DR providers executed before June 1, 2021). The program is available for projects completed between June 1, 2021 and May 31, 2026 under Act 129 Phase IV.

service_territories: Met-Ed service territory in eastern Pennsylvania
Penn Power service territory in western Pennsylvania
West Penn Power service territory in southwestern Pennsylvania
Penelec service territory in north-central and northwestern Pennsylvania

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program is available to commercial, industrial, governmental, and institutional customers of Met-Ed, Penn Power, and West Penn Power. Specific minimum kW requirements not disclosed in public documentation - details available through DR Program Service Providers (CPower, EnerNOC). For participation in PJM demand response programs integrated with this utility program, individual customers with 100 kW or more can participate directly; customers with less than 100 kW must aggregate through a Curtailment Service Provider.

eligibility.additional_notes: Specific technical eligibility requirements are determined by the DR Program Service Providers (CPower and EnerNOC Inc.). Customers must be served by one of FirstEnergy's four Pennsylvania utilities. Projects must be completed between June 1, 2021 and May 31, 2026 for Act 129 Phase IV participation. Governmental and institutional facilities are eligible in addition to commercial and industrial customers.

notification.notification_details: Notification procedures and timing are managed by the DR Program Service Providers (CPower and EnerNOC). Specific notification methods and advance notice requirements not disclosed in publicly available FirstEnergy program documentation. Contact service providers directly for notification protocol details.

seasonal_rates.season: Peak Demand Period (June 1 - August 30, M-F 2:00-6:00 PM excluding holidays)

capacity_rate.rate_details: Act 129 Phase IV offers up to $150/kW for demand reduction during the peak demand period of June 1 through August 30, Monday through Friday from 2:00 PM to 6:00 PM (excluding holidays and weekends). This is the capacity payment component for committed demand reduction.

performance_rate.rate_details: Incentives are paid at 5Â¢ per kWh for retail energy usage displaced from FirstEnergy's Pennsylvania utility distribution system. This is the energy/performance payment component based on actual kWh reduction achieved.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Penalty structure not disclosed in publicly available FirstEnergy program documentation. PJM demand response programs may include penalties for non-performance which would apply to participants integrated with PJM markets.

payment_structure.payment_details: Incentives are capped at 50 percent of total project cost, up to $500,000 maximum. By participating in energy efficiency and peak demand reduction programs, customers agree to allow FirstEnergy utilities to retain ownership of all PJM Capacity Rights (demand reduction attributes) which are aggregated into the PJM capacity market with proceeds used to offset program costs. Exception: Pennsylvania customers with existing contracts with third-party demand response service providers executed before June 1, 2021 (start of Act 129 Phase IV) have the option to retain PJM capacity rights when participating in FirstEnergy PA Act 129 programs.

pjm_integration.capacity_rights_ownership: FirstEnergy utilities retain PJM capacity rights for all demand reduction measures incentivized through Act 129 programs (unless customer has pre-existing third-party DR contract from before June 1, 2021)

pjm_capacity_payments_2024_2025.applicable_zones: Most PJM zones including FirstEnergy Pennsylvania territories

pjm_capacity_payments_2025_2026.applicable_zones: Most PJM zones including FirstEnergy Pennsylvania territories
pjm_capacity_payments_2025_2026.notes: Record-high capacity prices for 2025/2026 delivery year create favorable DR environment

pjm_minimum_requirements.aggregation_notes: Customers providing 100 kW or more can participate in PJM programs directly. Customers providing less than 100 kW must be aggregated through a Curtailment Service Provider (CSP). FERC Order 2222 mandates 100 kW as the maximum minimum offer size for DER aggregation in PJM.

pjm_energy_payments.calculation_method: Demand response participants in PJM's economic DR programs receive energy payments based on the real-time LMP at their nodal location during curtailment events. LMP = Energy Component + Congestion Component + Loss Component.
pjm_energy_payments.baseline_methodology: PJM uses customer baseline load (CBL) methodologies to calculate curtailment performance and energy payments

seasons.season_name: Act 129 Phase IV Peak Demand Period
seasons.notes: Peak demand period for incentive calculation runs June 1 through August 30 annually, Monday through Friday from 2:00 PM to 6:00 PM (excluding holidays and weekends). This is when the $150/kW demand reduction incentive applies. Program overall covers projects completed June 1, 2021 through May 31, 2026.

seasons: Act 129 Phase IV Peak Demand Period
call_windows.notes: Peak demand reduction period for Act 129 incentives: 2:00 PM to 6:00 PM on weekdays (excluding holidays). Actual DR event call windows may vary based on PJM integration and DR service provider dispatch protocols.

event_parameters.event_trigger_details: Event parameters are determined by DR Program Service Providers (CPower and EnerNOC) and may vary based on PJM market integration. Specific event frequency, duration, and dispatch requirements not disclosed in publicly available FirstEnergy program documentation. Contact service providers directly for detailed event parameters.

enrollment_period.notes: Act 129 Phase IV program period covers projects completed between June 1, 2021 and May 31, 2026. Enrollment and nomination procedures are managed by DR Program Service Providers. Contact CPower (844-422-8129) or EnerNOC for current enrollment availability.

special_programs.regulatory_framework: Pennsylvania Act 129 of 2008 mandates energy efficiency and conservation programs for the state's largest electric distribution companies. Program costs are recovered through customer rates. Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission (PA PUC) oversees program implementation and compliance.

program_evolution.change_description: Pennsylvania Act 129 signed into law, establishing energy efficiency and demand response requirements for large electric distribution companies.

FirstEnergy Pennsylvania utilities launched Commercial & Industrial Demand Response Program under Act 129 Phase III. Selected CPower and EnerNOC Inc. as approved DR Program Service Providers for four-year contract covering summers 2017-2020.

Act 129 Phase IV began June 1, 2021. Program expanded with updated incentive structure: $150/kW for demand reduction during peak periods (June 1-August 30, M-F 2-6 PM) and $0.05/kWh for energy displacement. Capacity rights provision updated: customers with pre-existing third-party DR contracts from before June 1, 2021 can retain PJM capacity rights; all new participants grant rights to utility.

PJM capacity market prices increased significantly for 2024/2025 delivery year ($28.92/MW-day) with record prices for 2025/2026 ($269.92/MW-day), creating more favorable economics for demand response participation. Franklin Energy designated as program implementer for FirstEnergy PA commercial and industrial energy efficiency programs.

integration_metadata.notes: FirstEnergy Pennsylvania's C&I Demand Response Program is suitable for commercial and industrial battery systems and load management resources. Program offers dual payment streams: capacity payments ($150/kW during peak periods June-August, M-F 2-6 PM) and energy payments ($0.05/kWh for displaced usage). Program is integrated with PJM wholesale markets, with utility retaining PJM capacity rights unless customer has pre-existing third-party DR contract from before June 1, 2021. Significant data gaps exist in publicly available documentation regarding specific event parameters, notification procedures, minimum kW requirements, and penalty structures. Customers must work with approved DR service providers (CPower, EnerNOC) for detailed technical requirements and enrollment. PJM integration provides additional revenue opportunities through capacity market (2025/2026 prices: $269.92/MW-day) and energy market LMP-based payments. API availability and automated dispatch capabilities not disclosed - contact service providers directly.

data_quality_assessment.researcher_notes: CRITICAL FINDINGS: (1) FirstEnergy PA C&I DR Program is well-suited for commercial/industrial battery systems and large load resources. (2) Program offers attractive dual payment structure: $150/kW capacity payments during peak periods (June-August, M-F 2-6 PM) plus $0.05/kWh energy payments for displaced usage. (3) Strong PJM integration with record-high capacity market prices for 2025/2026 delivery year ($269.92/MW-day) creating favorable economics. (4) IMPORTANT RESTRICTION: Utility retains all PJM capacity rights for demand reduction measures UNLESS customer has pre-existing third-party DR contract from before June 1, 2021 - this significantly impacts revenue potential for new participants who cannot directly monetize PJM capacity value. (5) Program administered by third-party service providers (CPower, EnerNOC) rather than directly by utility - contact providers for detailed technical requirements. (6) Significant data gaps in public documentation regarding event parameters, notification procedures, and operational details - much information requires direct engagement with service providers. (7) Act 129 program period runs through May 31, 2026 with incentives capped at 50% of project cost up to $500,000. (8) All data strictly sourced from official utility, service provider, PJM, and regulatory documents - no mock or invented data used per project requirements. (9) For PJM participation, 100 kW minimum applies (direct participation â¥100 kW, aggregation required for <100 kW). (10) Program has been operating since 2017 with service provider contracts for four-year periods.
